In 2016, the mayor (then vice mayor) was included in President Rodrigo Duterte's list of politicians alleged to be involved in the illegal drug trade. This led to his arrest then. The mayor was also investigated in the same year for a possible connection to the September 2016 bombing of a night market in Davao City.

source: Rappler; HRW; Manila Bulletin; Amnesty International
notes: On 10 February 2020, the government moved to shut down ABS CBN, the Philippines' largest broadcaster, by filing a petition at the Supreme Court in Manila challenging the validity of the media company's operating franchise. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has often been critical of what it perceived as biased journalism from ABS CBN and other media outlets. The Solicitor General's move came even as ABS CBN's operating franchise was set to expire on 30 March 2020, with Duterte threatening to direct his allies in Congress to block the franchise's renewal. This new development attracted widespread condemnation from journalist and left-wing groups and brought about a number of demonstrations. The office of the president denied that it had a hand in the Solicitor General's actions.

[size=no report]

On 11 February 2020, the Philippine government formally served the United States a notice of termination of the Visiting Forces Agreement, starting a 180-day transition period after which time the agreement will cease to be in force. The agreement, signed in 1999, is the legal basis for joint military exercises between the Philippines and the United States. Duterte had previously threatened to terminate the VFA due to US sanctions on Duterte's allies who jailed top government critic Senator Leila de Lima. On 2 June 2020, the Philippine government suspended for six months the VFA termination process. The Philippine military and the US welcomed the move, though the president's spokesperson clarified that the suspension does not mean the termination is being reversed.

Firefighters have heretofore not carried guns. The DILG explained that firefighters are allowed by law to carry guns in times of national emergency. The DILG said that arming firefighters is in line with Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's directive to engage the help of the BFP in maintaining law and order.

On 29 February 2020, a former NPA rebel was shot dead by suspected NPA militants in Barangay Kalilangan, Iligan, Lanao del Norte. The former rebel surrendered to the government the previous year.

On 29 February 2020, a civilian described as a police asset in the government drug war, as well as his partner, were shot dead by unidentified assailants in their home in Barangay Malabanban Sur, Candelaria, Quezon. The motive for the killings was unclear.

source: Abante; Philippine Daily Inquirer; Bohol Chronicle; Cebu Daily News; Sunstar (Philippines)
notes: On 29 February 2020, an NPA militant and a government soldier were killed during a 30-minute firefight between the NPA and the military in Barangay Cambigsi, Bilar, Bohol. The military said it retrieved weapons and other items from the rebels.
